interval.label: Health Check Interval
interval.description: How often to check the instance's reachability.

timeout.label: Request Timeout
timeout.description: How long to wait for a response from the instance.

validSsl.label: Validate SSL Certificate
validSsl.description: Checking the box makes sure the instance is using a valid SSL certificate.

deletes.label: Delete Content
deletes.description: This limits the number of delete requests that may be sent to this instance in an hour.
deletes.tooltip: This controls how many delete requests are allowed per hour. A setting of 0 disables the ability to send delete requests. This refers to media deletes, but may include other actions. This is a throttle to prevent hackers from obliterating your content.

testPattern.label: Test Pattern
testPattern.description: Example string or log line to test the regular expression against.
testPattern.placeholder: [INFO] 2025-05-25 16:20:01 - This is a test log line.

testRegex.label: Test Expression
testRegex.description: Expression to match against the test pattern.

phrases.VariableDescription: Notice: This configuration value is derived from an environment variable. Changing the value here will cause the new value to write to the config file, but it will not take affect. The next time you click save it will be replaced. Change the value here by changing the environment variable value, or by removing the variable from the environment.
phrases.ConfirmReloadBody: Are you sure you want to reload the client?
phrases.ReloadCheckTimedOut: Server reload check timed out after 20 attempts
phrases.ConfirmShutdownBody: Are you sure you want to shutdown the client? You will need to restart it from the host it runs on.
phrases.FailedToShutdown: Failed to shutdown: {error} - Try reloading the page.
phrases.LoginHelpBody: If you've forgotten your password, please see the forgotten passwords wiki page. If this is your first time logging in you can find your password in the client log file. If you provided an API key to the client before starting it for the first time, then your password is the API key.
phrases.ItsGone: It's gone! Don't forget to save.
phrases.URLMustBeginWithHttp: URL must begin with http:// or https://
phrases.NameInUseByInstance: This name is in use by instance {number}.
phrases.APIKeyMustBeCountCharacters: API key must be {count} characters or longer.
phrases.TokenMustBeCountCharacters: Token must be {count} characters or longer.
phrases.LeavePage: Do you really want to leave this page?

Landing.SelectASection: Select a section from the navigation menu to get started.

pageDescription.Configuration: Configure your Notifiarr client settings here.
pageDescription.SiteTunnel: This client keeps a persistent websocket connection to notifiarr.com using a Mulery tunnel. This tunnel allows the website to make requests to your client without the need for opening a port, or having a static IP. This page allows you to select your primary tunnel and which tunnel you wish to use as backup in case the primary becomes inaccessible.
pageDescription.MediaApps: Manage media players and related services.
pageDescription.SnapshotApps: Most snapshot configurations are on the Notifiarr.com website. Below you will find Application 'plugin' settings for the snapshot feature.
pageDescription.FileWatcher: Watch for file changes and trigger actions! This Notifiarr client can watch (log) files for lines matching a regular expression. This is similar to tail -f file | grep string and allows you to send notifications when, for instance, a log file has a new line written that matches a regular expression.
pageDescription.Endpoints: Configure relay endpoint URLs and their schedules.
pageDescription.Commands: Set up and execute custom commands and scripts.
pageDescription.Services: The Notifiarr client application is capable of monitoring services via HTTP checks, TCP port checks or process running (and not running) checks. The client service checks work with the Notifiarr.com Network Integration.
pageDescription.Actions: Find internal Notifiarr client actions here. These are executed by timers, schedules, and events from the website or a chat server. While usually reserved for troubleshooting, you may trigger them manually in this interface.
pageDescription.Integrations: This page displays data that this client application has cached in memory for the various configured integrations.
pageDescription.Metrics: View metric totals for client configurations.
pageDescription.LogFiles: View, follow, download and upload client log files.
pageDescription.System: View system and client information and.
pageDescription.TrustProfile: Configure how you log into this Notifiarr client application.
pageDescription.Landing: This is the greatest place on Earth!

errors.PleaseEnterBothUsernameAndPassword: Please enter both username and password.

apiKey.label: API Key
apiKey.description: API key from your Notifiarr.com account.
apiKey.tooltip: Find this by logging into Notifiarr.com, go to Profile then API Keys.

extraKeys.label: Extra Keys
extraKeys.description: Additional API keys for third-party integrations. Separate with newlines.

bindAddr.label: Bind Address
bindAddr.description: IP and port the app will listen on. Use 0.0.0.0 to listen on all interfaces.

sslKeyFile.label: SSL Key File
sslKeyFile.tooltip: This application can serve HTTPS. Enable that by specifying a certificate file path and key file path.

sslCertFile.label: SSL Certificate File
sslCertFile.tooltip: This application can serve HTTPS. Enable that by specifying a certificate file path and key file path.

debug.label: Debug Logging
debug.tooltip: Enabling Debug will write a lot more data to the log. Use Max Body settings to control payloads sizes.

quiet.label: Quiet Logging
quiet.tooltip: Enabling Quiet makes the app not print anything to stdout. This is useful when a log file is enabled and you don't want logs spewing into a startup daemon too.

logFile.label: Application Log File
logFile.description: Path to the application log file or folder.
logFile.tooltip: If you set a folder without a file name, the application will create a file named Notifiarr.log in the folder.

httpLog.label: HTTP Log File
httpLog.description: Path to the HTTP log file or folder.
httpLog.tooltip: Setting a log file path here will make the application write the HTTP logs to a dedicated file. The file format is in apache log. Highly recommended. If you set a folder without a file name, the application will create a file named Notifiarr.http.log in the folder.

debugLog.label: Debug Log File
debugLog.description: Path to the debug log file or folder.
debugLog.tooltip: Setting a log file path here will make the application write the debug logs to a dedicated file. Debug logs are written to the application log file when this is unset. If you set a folder without a file name, the application will create a file named Notifiarr.debug.log in the folder.

maxBody.label: Max Body Size
maxBody.description: Maximum body size for HTTP requests.
maxBody.tooltip: When debug is enabled, this setting limits the amount of payload data written to the log, to or from Notifiarr.com.

logFileMb.label: Log File Size
logFileMb.description: Maximum size of the log file before rotation.
logFileMb.tooltip: When rotation is enabled (setting Max Log File Count higher than 1), this setting controls how large a file must be to trigger rotation.

logFiles.label: Log File Count
logFiles.description: Number of log files to keep.
logFiles.tooltip: When this setting is 0 or 1, log file rotation is disabled. This setting applies to all log files, and will keep this many of each on disk.

noUploads.label: Deny Uploads
noUploads.description: Disabled allows Notifiarr.com administrators to make this client upload log files to the website. Enabled prevents log file uploads.
noUploads.tooltip: This setting controls the Notifiarr.com website and Notifiarr administrators' ability to trigger this client to upload log files to the website. Sometimes we need to see log entries while diagnosing problems and this trigger allows us to make the client upload the app and debug log files.

disabled.label: Service Checks
disabled.tooltip: Disable or enable monitoring all network and service checks right here.

parallel.label: Parallel Checks
parallel.tooltip: Normally running service checks 1 at a time is fine, but if you have more than 30 or 40, you may want to increase this.

logFile.label: Services Log File
logFile.description: Path to the services log file or folder.
logFile.tooltip: The log file is used to store the service check results. If left unset, the service check output is written to the application log file. If you set a folder without a file name, the application will create a file named Notifiarr.services.log in the folder.

path.label: File Path
path.description: Path to the file to watch.

urlbase.label: URL Base
urlbase.description: This application serves HTTP on / by default. You can change that by typing in something else here.

hostId.label: Host ID
hostId.description: The Host ID parameter is used to uniquely identify this client installation.
hostId.tooltip: Changing this value is discouraged; it should be found automatically. Do not copy this value to another Notifiarr client installation.

serial.label: Parallel Threads
serial.description: Disabling this setting will make the application use fewer go routines (threads) when gathering data from configured applications.
serial.tooltip: Spreads out CPU usage and lowers memory footprint.

retries.label: Retries
retries.description: Sometimes connections to Notifiarr.com fail. This controls how many times each request will be attempted in case of failures.

apt.label: APT Hook
apt.description: The Notifiarr Debian (and Ubuntu) packages include an APT integration.
apt.tooltip: The Notifiarr Debian (and Ubuntu) packages include an APT integration. This integration invokes every time an apt command is executed. To enable it, set this field to Enabled, and then enable the Package Manager integration on Notifiarr.com. This feature does not require the client to be running; it only requires the client deb package to be installed. This does not work on RHEL or non-Debian Linux.

timeout.label: Timeout
timeout.description: This is the timeout for API requests to Notifiarr.com.

fileMode.label: Log File Unix Mode
fileMode.description: This is the unix file mode used when writing new log files.
fileMode.tooltip: Recommended values in order of openness: 0600, 0640, 0644

autoUpdate.label: Auto Update
autoUpdate.description: This is how often the application will check for updates. When one is found it will be installed automatically.

unstableCh.label: Unstable Channel
unstableCh.description: Enabling the unstable updates channel will make the application check the unstable website for auto-updates instead of GitHub.
unstableCh.tooltip: Only available to users with developer access.

phrase.ShowMoreDesc: Three authentication types are currently supported. Auth Proxy and No Password are only available if the current request comes from a valid, configured upstream IP address.
phrase.PasswordOnlyUsed: Username and Password are only used if Authentication Type is set to Password.
phrase.HeaderOnlyUsed: Auth Header is only used if Authentication Type is not set to Password.
phrase.AuthTypeChange: If Authentication Type changes, log out to complete the process.
phrase.EnterCurrentPassword: Enter your current password to make changes.
phrase.ProxyAuthDisabled: Proxy authentication is disabled because your upstream ({upstreamIp}) is not in the allowed upstreams list.
phrase.SeeWikiForAuthProxyHelp: See the wiki for instructions setting up an authentication proxy.

authType.label: Authentication Type
authType.description: Select how to authenticate with the client

option_desc.password: This is the default authentication type. Select the Password option to log into this application with a configured username and password. Only 1 username and password is supported. When selecting this option, you must fill in the username and new password fields. If this is the current authentication type you must also fill in the current password field to make changes.
option_desc.header: Select this option to log into this application using an HTTP header that contains a username. This is commonly known as proxy authentication. We have a wiki page that provides instructions to configure Nginx for this feature. When selecting this option, you must also select a header for the auth proxy. If no headers are displayed, then no valid headers were provided by the upstream proxy.
option_desc.noauth: This configuration is not recommended. The No Password authentication type allows any request from any configured upstream IP. It also works with an auth proxy to set the username. If no username is in the provided header, then it defaults to admin.

upstreams.label: Upstreams
upstreams.description: Trusted proxy IP or CIDR networks. Separate networks with spaces.
upstreams.tooltip: If Notifiarr client is behind a reverse proxy (swag, nginx, etc), then you should add that proxy's IP here. You can also specify full networks. This controls which IP is written to the web server log file, requester or X-Forwarded-For header. Required when using a request header for authentication, or when authentication is disabled.

header.label: Auth Header
header.description: Select the header containing your username
header.tooltip: This displays headers that are provided by the client or upstream that may be used for proxy authentication. This selection is used if Authentication Type is set to Header or No Password. Choose the header that displays your proper username. When using No Password, the header is used to set the username, but is not required.

UserInformation.title: User Information
UserInformation.YoureSoGifted: You're so gifted, and we love you! ðŸ’œ

Plex.title: Plex
Plex.description: The Plex integration is comprehensive, and many of the settings are configured on the Notifiarr.com website.

name.label: Server Name
name.tooltip: The name of the Plex Media Server is used in notifications, logs and service checks. It is set automatically by the Plex server.

token.label: Token
token.tooltip: You may find directions for locating your Plex token at this Plex Article.

Tautulli.title: Tautulli
Tautulli.description: Tautulli provides a feature that allows you to give your Plex users custom usernames. By integrating Notifiarr client with Tautulli, those custom usernames will be displayed in your chat server notifications. When not enabled, Plex usernames or email addresses are used instead. This is entirely optional. The Notifiarr website also provides this same feature and allows you to map Plex users to custom names. You may also add a Tautulli instance here simply to monitor it with service checks.

apiKey.label: API Key
apiKey.description: API key for the Tautulli service.

MySQL.title: MySQL
MySQL.description: You may add MySQL credentials to your Notifiarr client configuration to snapshot MySQL service health. This feature snapshots SHOW PROCESSLIST and SHOW STATUS data. Access to a database is not required. Example Grant: GRANT PROCESS ON *.* to 'notifiarr'@'localhost'

host.label: Host
host.description: Host or IP address of the MySQL server.

Nvidia.title: Nvidia
Nvidia.description: This integration displays Nvidia CUDA info in Snapshot notifications. To use this feature in Docker, you must use the CUDA image: ghcr.io/notifiarr/notifiarr:cuda

busIds.label: Bus IDs
busIds.description: Comma separated list of bus IDs to snapshot.
busIds.tooltip: This is the bus ID of the GPU. You can find this by running nvidia-smi and looking at the Bus Id column. Cards with other Bus IDs are ignored in the snapshot. Generally, just leave this blank. Add multiple with newlines.

smiPath.label: nvidia-smi Path
smiPath.tooltip: If nvidia-smi (nvidia-smi.exe on Windows) is not in the PATH environment, then you may provide a full path to the binary here.

apiKey.label: API Key
apiKey.description: API key for the Radarr instance.

username.label: Username
username.tooltip: You only need a username and password if you want to check database backups since those cannot be downloaded through the API.

apiKey.label: API Key
apiKey.description: API key for the Sonarr instance.

username.label: Username
username.tooltip: You only need a username and password if you want to check database backups since those cannot be downloaded through the API.

apiKey.label: API Key
apiKey.description: API key for the Readarr instance.

username.label: Username
username.tooltip: You only need a username and password if you want to check database backups since those cannot be downloaded through the API.

apiKey.label: API Key
apiKey.description: API key for the Lidarr instance.

username.label: Username
username.tooltip: You only need a username and password if you want to check database backups since those cannot be downloaded through the API.

apiKey.label: API Key
apiKey.description: API key for the Prowlarr instance.

username.label: Username
username.tooltip: You only need a username and password if you want to check database backups since those cannot be downloaded through the API.

url.label: URL
url.description: URL of the Transmission instance. It must include the /transmission/rpc suffix.

apiKey.label: API Key
apiKey.description: API key for the SabNZB instance.

SiteTunnel.subText: Click the Ping Tunnels button, and select the tunnel with the fastest response time as your primary. Select another fast tunnel as backup.

phrases.TunnelStatsStale: The data above is always stale. To update it, click the update backend link in the page header.

FileWatcher.title: Watched Files
FileWatcher.description: You must enable the Log Watcher feature and choose a channel on the Notifiarr website for this to work!

path.label: File Path
path.description: Path to the file to watch. Recommend absolute path names.

regex.label: Regular Expression
regex.description: Regex to match against the file.
regex.tooltip: Expressions are automatically wrapped in a wildcard matcher: .* so do not use ^ or $ in your expression. Use (?i) as a prefix to make regular expressions case insensitive.

skip.label: Skip Expressions
skip.description: Anything matching this expression is ignored.

poll.label: File Polling
poll.tooltip: File system events do not work on some systems. If nothing is being matched, turn this on to enable the file poller interval.

pipe.label: FIFO Pipe
pipe.description: Path is a named FIFO pipe.
pipe.tooltip: Enable this if the file you're watching is a named FIFO pipe. You probably don't need this.

mustExist.label: File Must Exist
mustExist.description: Skip watching file if it's missing.
mustExist.tooltip: Enabling this will skip watching the file if it does not exist when the application starts. Watching files that do not exist is still buggy and may not work at all.

logMatch.label: Log Matches
logMatch.description: Write matched lines to notifiarr log.
logMatch.tooltip: Enabling this will write the matched line to the notifiarr log. This is good for debugging, but may be noisy.

Commands.title: Command List
Commands.description: Commands are executed by the client (the backend). They can be triggered from this interface or from a chat server. If you modify a command you must save the configuration before you can run it from the Web UI.
Commands.commandRequiresArguments: This command requires {count, plural, =1 {one argument. Enter it below.} other {# arguments. Enter them below.}}
Commands.noOutput: No output yet. Try executing the command then click refresh.
Commands.regexMismatch: Argument does not match regular expression.

name.label: Name
name.description: Name of the command. Shows up in the log and in notifications.

command.label: Command
command.tooltip:
This is the command that will execute when triggered.
Click the double-check icon to run the command right now. After it finishes, click refresh and show output to see the results.

Check the box to wrap the command in a shell. On Windows, this will run the command with cmd.exe and on other operating systems, it will run the command with /bin/bash. This is useful for commands that require shell features like pipes and redirects. Custom positional arguments may be defined with this format: ({regex}) - that is a regular expression wrapped in curly braces and parentheses, ie. ({[a-z]}). These arguments may be filled in by the person running the command; either in this Web UI or on your chat server. If a command has an argument, it is required; if it has multiple arguments, they're all required.

Examples
Command using two arguments: /bin/ls ({-la|-l|-a|-al}) ({/tmp|/|/home|/lib})
The above command will allow a user to do any combination of ls -la on either /tmp, /, /home, or /lib.
This command can be used to curl websites from within the scratch Docker container: /notifiarr --curl ({https?://[^ ;]+})

notify.label: Notify
notify.description: Send notification after command is executed.
notify.tooltip: Receive a notification containing the command output.

log.label: Log Output
log.tooltip: Log the command output to this client's application log.

timeout.label: Maximum Run Duration
timeout.description: How long the command may run before termination.

scheduler.title: Schedule
scheduler.selectAFrequency: Select a frequency to create a schedule.
scheduler.empty: If you want to run every day, select the Daily Frequency.

required.daysOfWeek: Must select at least one day of the week.
required.daysOfMonth: Must select at least one day of the month.
required.atTimes: Must select at least one time to run the schedule.

times.everyMinute: {count, plural, =1 {One time} other {# times}} every minute at seconds {times}
times.everyHour: {count, plural, =1 {One time} other {# times}} every hour at minute:seconds {times}
times.everyDay: {count, plural, =1 {One time} other {# times}} every day at times {times}
times.everyWeek: {count, plural, =1 {One time} other {# times}} every week on {daysOfWeek} at times {times}
times.everyMonth: {count, plural, =1 {One time} other {# times}} every month on days {daysOfMonth} at times {times}

template.label: Payload Template
template.tooltip: The template is used by the website to figure out how to turn the payload into a chat notification. Find a list of available templates or create your own on the website @ Integrations: Endpoints.
template.required: A template is required. Enter 'test' if you are not sure what to enter.

timeout.label: Request Timeout
timeout.description: How long to wait for the HTTP request to complete.

url.label: Relay URL
url.description: URL for remote service that gets relayed to the website.

header.label: HTTP Headers
header.tooltip: The HTTP request headers are sent to the URL as is. The format must be key: value per line. The space and colon are required. Invalid values are ignored and extra spaces are trimmed.

query.label: Query Parameters
query.description: Query parameters to add to the URL, 1 per line.
query.tooltip: The query parameters are appended to the URL. The format must be key=value per line. Invalid values are ignored and extra spaces are trimmed. Do not include the ? character or ampersand (&) at the beginning of a line. Keys and values are automatically URL encoded.

body.label: Request Body
body.description: The body sent to the URL for POST, PUT and PATCH requests.

metrics.CountersReset: The counters on this page reset when the application exits.

httpRequests.title: HTTP Requests
httpRequests.description: Incoming HTTP request statistics. This includes websocket tunnel requests.

apps.title: Application Requests
apps.description: Application request statistics. These counters do not include service checks.

monitoring.ConfigureServices: Service checks for configured integrations are enabled by giving them a check interval on their respective configuration pages. Some of these checks are from the <go-to page="starrapps">Starr Apps</go-to> page, or the <go-to page="downloaders">Download Apps</go-to> page, or the <go-to page="mediaapps">Media Apps</go-to> page. The rest of the service checks displayed can be found on the <go-to page="services">Services page</go-to>.
monitoring.EnableOnConfig: Enable service checks on the <go-to page="configuration">Configuration</go-to> page.

last.title: Last Check: {timeDuration} ago
last.tooltip: How long ago this service was checked.

since.title: Time in state: {timeDuration}
since.tooltip: How long the service has been in this state.
since.description: Service has been in this state since

interval.title: Check Interval
interval.tooltip: How often this service is checked.

ServiceChecks.title: Health Checks
ServiceChecks.description: Use this form to configure service checks. Do not add starr, media, snapshot, or downloader apps here. Give them a check interval on their respective configuration pages instead. Disable and Enable service health checks in whole on the <go-to page="configuration">Configuration</go-to> page. View running service health information on the <go-to page="monitoring">Monitoring</go-to> page. View the <go-to page="ProcessList">running process list here</go-to>, and use it for inspiration when creating process checks.
ServiceChecks.processListLink: View the running process list here.

timeout.label: Check Timeout
timeout.description: How long to wait for the service check to complete.

interval.label: Check Interval
interval.description: How often to check the service.

name.label: Check Name
name.description: Unique name for the service being monitored.
name.tooltip: The name of the service being monitored. This is used to identify the service in notifications. Each service must have a unique name.

type.label: Check Type
type.description: The type of check to perform.
type.tooltip: The Process check type allows you to monitor that a process is running. The HTTP URL check type allows you to monitor a URL for reachability. The TCP Port check type allows you to monitor a TCP port's connectivity. Both Ping check types allow monitoring an IP or host for reachability.

url.label: URL
url.description: URL of the service being monitored.

codes.label: Acceptable Response Codes
codes.description: Any code here is considered acceptable. If the service responds with another code a notification is generated.
codes.required: At least one expected response code is required.

value.label: Host and Port
value.description: Enter host:port or host:ip to check connectivity.
value.tooltip: An IP address is generally recommended. If you also want to test DNS, use a hostname. The format is host:port. There should be no spaces or extra characters.
value.required: A host and port separated with a colon are required.

value.label: Host or IP
value.description: Enter host or ip to check reachability.
value.tooltip: An IP address is generally recommended. If you also want to test DNS, use a hostname. The format is host or 10.11.12.13. There should be no spaces or extra characters. To allow UDP checks to work on Linux, you must enable them with this command: sudo sysctl -w net.ipv4.ping_group_range="0 2147483647". To allow ICMP checks in Linux, you must give the notifiarr binary capabilities with this command: sudo setcap cap_net_raw=+ep /usr/bin/notifiarr. Easiest way to make both work in Docker is to enable privileged mode, but you may set capabilities too.
value.required: A host or IP address is required.

count.label: Count
count.required: A count of packets greater than zero is required.

minimum.label: Minimum
minimum.description: Minimum number of packets that must be received.
minimum.required: A minimum number of packets greater than zero is required.

value.label: Process Match
value.description: The name of the process to check.
value.tooltip: The name of the process to check. This is the name of the process as it appears in the process list. A wildcard string match is used on both ends of the value provided, so the more specific your arguments the better the match will be.

running.label: Running
running.description: Send an alert if the process is running.
running.tooltip: Selecting this will trigger an unhealthy alert if the process is found running. Select this option if you need a notification when the process starts.

restarts.label: Restarts
restarts.description: Send an alert if the process has restarted.
restarts.tooltip: Selecting this will trigger an unhealthy alert if the process is found to have restarted. Select this option if you need a notification when the PID changes.

minimum.label: Minimum
minimum.description: Minimum number of running processes that must match the value.
minimum.required: A minimum number of processes greater than zero is required.
minimum.tooltip: If you enter 2, then you will receive a notification if there are fewer than 2 processes running. Use this to be alerted if there are too few processes running.

maximum.label: Maximum
maximum.description: Maximum number of running processes that may match the value.
maximum.tooltip: If you enter 2, then you will receive a notification if there are more than 2 processes running. Use this to be alerted if there are too many processes running.

descriptions.Triggers: These actions have no timer and no schedule.
descriptions.SiteCrons: These actions are created by the website to offload timer tracking.

TrigCFSyncLidarr.label: Lidarr profile and format sync
TrigCFSyncLidarr.success: Lidarr profile and format sync initiated.

TrigCFSyncRadarr.label: Radarr profile and format sync
TrigCFSyncRadarr.success: Radarr profile and format sync initiated.

TrigCFSyncSonarr.label: Sonarr profile and format sync
TrigCFSyncSonarr.success: Sonarr profile and format sync initiated.

TrigCFSyncLidarrInt.label: Lidarr custom format sync per instance

TrigCFSyncRadarrInt.label: Radarr custom format sync per instance

TrigCFSyncSonarrInt.label: Sonarr custom format sync per instance

button.tooltip: The Download button downloads the file to your computer. The Upload button uploads the file to the Notifiarr.com server. Only administrators can see uploaded files. The Delete button deletes the file from your hard drive. Files that are in use cannot be deleted. In use means this application is currently writing log entries to it.

LogFiles.deleteConfirm: Are you sure you want to delete this file? This action cannot be undone.
LogFiles.SelectFile: Select a file to see what's in it!
LogFiles.FollowTooltip: The buttons in this column actively follow a file as it's being written to.
LogFiles.Tooltip:
1. The first orange button on the left toggles the order of the lines in the file. By default it's ordered descending in the order it's written. Clicking the button reverses the file and makes it backward. This works well when following a file that's being written to.
  2. The second purple button toggles the built-in line highlight colors. It also spins when things are happening.
  3. The number input indicates how many lines to load or add. When following a file, the number limits how many lines are displayed.
  4. Clicking the Add button adds the number of lines to the top of the file using the existing line count as the offset. The Add button is disabled on in-use files because it's impossible to know how many lines were written since the last update. When following in-use files, the Add button is replaced by an indicator.
  5. Clicking the Reload button reloads the number of lines from the end of the file.
  6. Use the highlight input to make specific text stand out.
  7. The last button toggles line wrapping.

ClientInfo.title: Startup Payload
ClientInfo.description: This is the payload that was sent to the client from Notifiarr.com when it started. It contains the client's configuration and other information.

plexSessions.title: Current Plex Media Server Sessions
plexSessions.footer: Displaying current Plex sessions, not the cached data. See the raw JSON modal for the cached data.

Languages.title: Localization Support
Languages.body: This application is available in multiple languages. You can change the language by clicking the language selector in the profile menu. Some languages do not have active translators, so some translations may be incomplete. If you are interested in helping translate the application, please visit us on Discord. Head into the #role-request channel and type !roleTranslate. That gives you access to the #translate channel. Please join there and express your interest.

ApiDocs.Contrast: Please report any contrast problems with this page.

api.title: Private API ({basePath})
api.body: This is the API specification for the Notifiarr.com website. The website uses this API to interact with the client.

ui.title: Web UI ({basePath})
ui.body: This specification is for the methods used by the Notifiarr Client frontend to interact with the backend. You're using the frontend right now.

TestAllInstances.title: Test All Instances
TestAllInstances.clickRefresh: Click the refresh button in the top-right to test again.
TestAllInstances.footer: Use this troubleshooting tool to verify that all your instances are reachable and configured correctly. The timeout is hard coded to 15 seconds, which is close to how long the website will wait for a response.

FileBrowser.CreateFileIn: The file will be created in the path: {path}
FileBrowser.CreateFolderIn: The folder will be created in the path: {path}
FileBrowser.InvalidPath: Invalid path provided. Do not include slashes (/ or \).
FileBrowser.FilterFilesDesc: Use the file filter to quickly search the list of displayed files. Useful on folders with a lot of files. Use the Menu button to create a new folder or file. To select a file that does not exist, type it into the Path bar and click the green check button. Alternatively, use the Create File menu item to create it.

Plex.URLNotConfigured: Plex URL is not configured. <go-to page="mediaApps" subPage="plex">Configure that here</go-to>.
Plex.TokenNotConfigured: Plex Token is not configured. <go-to page="mediaApps" subPage="plex">Configure that here</go-to>.
Plex.Disabled: Plex is administratively disabled. <go-to page="mediaApps" subPage="plex">Enable it here</go-to>.
Plex.NoStatus: There is no Plex Media Server information cached. This could mean the Plex URL or Token is invalid, or the timeout is too short. Check the <go-to page="logFiles">application logs</go-to> for more information.
Plex.WebhookNote:
Did you already configure the Plex Webhook?

If the webhook counter is not incrementing when you pause and play a show, try restarting Plex Media Server. If that does not work, check the http logs for invalid requests. If you don't see any, it may mean you have the wrong webhook URL configured in Plex. It should look like this: {webhookUrl} but this may not be accurate and depends on your server configuration.

Some web providers block access to the {urlbase}plex URI, so this application also accepts a Plex webhook at the {urlbase} URI and at {urlbase}api/plex/post. We offer versitility to ensure stable notifications.
